abstract.text: Add a Live Text interface that enables users to perform actions with text and QR
codes that appear in images.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Enabling Live Text interactions with images

inlineContent.text: Enhance the user experience with images in your app by adding standard Live Text
interactions. Live Text lets users tap text in an image to copy it, make a call,
send an email, translate it, or look up directions. VisionKit provides this familiar
Live Text interface to your images and across platforms.
For iOS apps, users can use a long-press gesture (touch and hold) a QR code to follow
a link or take another action, depending on the payload. The payload is the data
that a QR code contains, such as a URL or email address.
Before interacting with items in an image, the user can tap the Live Text button
in the lower-right corner to highlight the recognized items. Then a data-specific
action menu appears when the user double-taps on text in an image, and uses a long-press
gesture on an email address or QR code.
In your app, you decide whether Live Text recognizes text and data within text, and
for iOS apps, QR codes in the image. You choose the types of items to look for and
run the analysis on the image, and then VisionKit provides the entire Live Text interface
with the breadth of actions for specific types.
The code listings in this article use asynchronous methods that you
invoke from an
method or within a
structure. For details on asynchronous flows, see

content.text: Check whether the device supports Live Text

inlineContent.text: Before showing a Live Text interface in your app, check whether the device supports
Live Text. For iOS apps, the image analyzer is available only on devices with the
A12 Bionic chip and later. If the
property is
, show the
Live Text interface. Otherwise, disable any feature in your app that relies on Live
Text. If you attempt to start the Live Text interface when this property is
the interface doesnâ€™t appear.

content.text: Add a Live Text interaction object to your view in iOS

inlineContent.text: For iOS apps, you add the Live Text interface by adding an interaction object to
the view containing the image. If you use a
to display the image, it handles the image content area calculations for you.
Add an
object directly on the view containing
the image.
Optionally, customize the interface by setting the interactionâ€™s delegate to an object
that implements the
protocol methods.
If you donâ€™t use a
object, inform the interaction object when the content area of the image changes
while the interaction bounds donâ€™t change. Implement the
protocol method
to return the content area of the image. This keeps the Live Text highlights within
the bounds of the image. Then use the
method to notify the interaction if the content area changes.

content.text: Add a Live Text view to your image view in macOS

inlineContent.text: For macOS apps, add the Live Text interface by adding a view above the view containing
the image. If you use an
to display the image, it handles the image content area calculations for you.
First create an instance of the
class.
Then configure the overlay view to fit the bounds of the image. If your view is an
image view, set the
property
so that the dimensions adjust when the scaling and alignment properties change.
Add the overlay view above the image in the hierarchy. For example, add it as a subview
of the view containing the image.
To customize the interface, set the overlay viewâ€™s delegate to an object that implements
the optional
protocol methods.
Implement the
protocol method to return
to begin the interaction.
If you arenâ€™t using an
object, implement the
protocol method to return the content area of the image. Then use the
method to notify the overlay view if the content area of the image changes while
the view bounds donâ€™t change.

content.text: Find items and start the interaction with an image

inlineContent.text: Process the image that your view displays using an
object.
First, specify the types of items in the image you want to find when you create an
object. For iOS apps, the analyzer recognizes
both text and machine-readable QR codes in an image; for macOS apps, the analyzer
recognizes text in an image.
Then analyze the image by sending
to an
object, passing the image and the configuration.
To improve performance, use a single shared instance of the analyzer throughout the
app.

code: let analysis = try? await analyzer.analyze(image, configuration: configuration)

inlineContent.text: For iOS apps, start the Live Text interface by setting the
property of the
object to the results of the
analyze method. For example, set the
property in the action method of a control that starts Live Text.
For macOS apps, start the Live Text interface by setting the
property of the
object.
The standard Live Text menu appears when users click and hold items in the image.
The user chooses actions from this menu, depending on the type of item.
You can change the behavior of the interface by enabling types of interactions with
items the analyzer finds in the image. If you set the interaction or overlay view
property to
users can interact with all types of items that the analyzer finds.
If you set the
property
to just
, users
can only select text in the image and then perform a basic text action, such as copying,
translating, or sharing the text. For iOS apps, if the
objectâ€™s
property is
, users can also touch and hold text that contains data (URLs,
phone numbers, and email addresses) to perform a data-specific action.
For iOS apps, users can tap the Live Text button in the lower-right corner to switch
to highlight mode. Then users can touch and hold data that the analyzer detects in
text to perform a data-specific action, such as opening a URL, calling a phone number,
or sending an email.
To let users interact with data that the analyzer detects in text in macOS, set the
property to
Then users can hover over data in text to perform a data-specific action.
For iOS apps only, users can touch and hold QR codes and perform an action, depending
on the payload, such as following an embedded link. To enable QR code interactions,
set the
structureâ€™s
property to
You can modify the Live Text supplementary interface to conform better to the look
of your app. The supplementary interface consists of the quick actions in the lower-left
corner and the Live Text button in the lower-right corner of the interface.
To hide the supplementary interface, set the
to
. For iOS apps, if
the
property is
, users can
still touch and hold text to perform data-specific actions.
If your interface overlaps the supplementary interface, set the
property appropriately to move the quick actions and Live Text button.
If you want the supplementary interface to use a custom font, set the
property. Quick actions use the specified font for text and font weight for symbols.
For button size consistency, the Live Text interface ignores the point size.
By default the image analyzer attempts to recognize the userâ€™s preferred languages.
If you want the analyzer to consider other languages, set the
property of the
object.
To determine whether the image analyzer supports a language, check whether the array
that the
class property returns includes the language ID.
For more information on language IDs, see

abstract.text: Identify and extract information in the environment using the deviceâ€™s camera, or in images that your app displays.
An object that represents the results of analyzing an image, and provides
the input for the Live Text interface object.
An interface that enables people to interact with recognized text, barcodes, and other objects in an image.
An option that enables interaction with any type of text, symbols, or subjects that the framework recognizes.
An option that enables text selection, copying, and translating.
A Boolean value that indicates whether people can press and hold text to
activate data detectors.
The results of analyzing an image for items that people can interact
with.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view hides supplementary
interface objects.
The types of interactions that people can perform with the image.
Informs the view that contains the image when the layout changes and the
view needs to reload its content.
The distances the edges of content are inset from the supplementary
interface.
The font to use for the supplementary interface.
A delegate that handles image-analysis and user-interaction callbacks for an interaction object.
Returns the rectangle, in unit coordinates, that contains the image within the view.
A view that enables people to interact with recognized text, barcodes, and other objects in an image.
An option that enables interaction with text of certain formats,
such as URLs, email addresses, and physical addresses.
The results of analyzing an image for items that people can interact with.
The types of interactions that people can perform with the image in this overlay view.
Informs the view that contains the image when the layout changes and the view needs to reload its content.
The image view that contains the image.
A delegate that handles image-analysis and user-interaction callbacks for an overlay view.
A default implementation that returns a rectangle that specifies the full width and height of the view.
Indicates whether interaction begins at the given point for the specified interaction type.
An object that finds items in images that people can interact with, such
as subjects, text, and QR codes.
An option that analyzes an image for machine-readable codes, such as QR codes.
A configuration that specifies the types of items and locales that the
image analyzer recognizes.
The types of items that the image analyzer looks for in the image.
The languages to use in text items that the image analyzer
recognizes.
Returns the data for providing a Live Text interaction with an image.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the device supports image analysis.
The identifiers for the languages that the image analyzer recognizes.
A display of image data in a frame.
A unit of asynchronous work.
Perform asynchronous and parallel operations.
A view that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.
Add a language-only localization or localizations specific to regional variants and scripts.

enabling_live_text_interactions_with_ima.alt: A mockup of three iPhone screens showing the Live Text button and highlighted text with its action menu, a long press of an email address with its action menu, and a long press of a QR code with its action menu.
A diagram showing an image that is offset in an arbitrary view with the overlay view on top of it.
A mockup of the lower half of an iPhone screen showing the Live Text button enabled and recognized items highlighted, such as a mailing address and QR code.
